Situation1: They occasionally participate in family traditions during holidays and gatherings.
Expectation2: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation2: The mentor assigned a code sample to be finished before the next meeting in three days.
Story:
I sat at my desk, laptop open, the cursor blinking on a half-finished code sample. My mentor’s words echoed in my mind: “I expect you to have this ready before our next meeting.” The deadline was in three days, and I knew he would check every detail. But downstairs, I could hear my family laughing, the clatter of dishes, and the familiar scent of my mother’s special holiday stew drifting up the stairs. Tonight was the start of our family’s annual holiday tradition—a time when everyone was expected to be present, to share stories, and to honor the rituals that meant so much to my parents.

My father had already called up once, reminding me, “This is important to your mother and me. We don’t get these moments often.” I felt the weight of their expectations pressing down, the unspoken rule that family comes first. But the code on my screen demanded my attention, and I knew my mentor would be disappointed if I let him down. Torn between the warmth of family tradition and the responsibility to my mentor, I sat frozen, heart pounding, unable to move in either direction.
